;

;Recently, a security case has attracted attention. According to the Zhuzhou police report, the man Yi Mou uses paid "scolding" on the Internet as a way to make money. According to the customer's requirements, he personally attacks and insults specific objects through WeChat and phone calls, and charges fees ranging from 20 to 30 yuan. , causing serious impact on the victim’s work and life. From February 2023 to now, Yi has made more than 3,000 yuan in profits by relying on such illegal services. Currently, Yi has been placed under administrative detention.

;

;This is not the first time that practitioners of scolding have been punished. In August 2023, the police in Changsha, Hunan Province captured Li Moudong, who posted a "swearing" advertisement online, and detained him in accordance with the law. According to police investigation, Li Moudong helped customers verbally abuse others online on designated social platforms for 100 yuan a day, and has made illegal profits of nearly 10,000 yuan since October 2022.

;

;The risk of "scolding on behalf of others" is that the person being scolded may call the police. Article 42 of the "Public Security Administration Punishment Law of the People's Republic of China" stipulates that "repeatedly sending obscene, insulting, threatening or other information that interferes with the normal life of others" constitutes a violation and shall be detained for not more than five days or fined not more than 500 yuan; if the circumstances are serious, In serious cases, the offender shall be detained for not less than five days but not more than ten days, and may also be fined not more than five hundred yuan.

;

;While the police punish the illegal behavior of "screamers", there are also several issues worthy of in-depth consideration.

;

;First, scolding has already broken the law. Do people who purchase "scolding services" need to bear legal responsibility? In other words, by spending this money, the buyer can "use someone's mouth to curse others", thereby achieving the effect of "using a borrowed knife to kill people", and can still exempt themselves from responsibility? Judging from this case, Yi has replaced at least a hundred people to insult others. If there are cases of "serious consequences", then the person who paid for the "mouth substitute" has become a hidden "behind-the-scenes manipulator" , you can brazenly "buy evil and curse others". Is this because the target of each business is too small and not handled?

;

;The "Civil Code of the People's Republic of China" stipulates that if two or more people jointly commit infringement and cause damage to others, they shall bear joint and several liability. Anyone who instigates or helps others commit infringements shall bear joint and several liability with the perpetrator. Theoretically, the person who purchases the scolding service is the source of the infringement, which meets the identification standard of "instigating and helping others to commit infringement".

;

;Secondly, "swearing" itself is a very broad and general concept, and there is a problem of how to define it. Which verbal attacks are considered curses, and which curses are personal attacks and insults that are suspected of illegal crimes? There is still a very large range of distribution, and it is not suitable to generalize.

;

;It is also "swearing" in a broad sense. Verbal counterattacks after encountering injustice are obviously not comparable to organized and premeditated verbal bullying and insults. The former can be regarded as legitimate in language no matter how you say it. defensive. In addition to the "cussing service", there is also the "quarrel service". This kind of "storm in the teapot" is less likely to be suspected of illegal crimes. Following this line of thinking, the old-school literati's "knowing yourself and your enemy", "stopping in moderation", "speaking elegantly" and "retreating in order to advance" - these "elegant scolding" tactics used today are still outdated, and I am afraid it will be more difficult to classify them as words and deeds that violate the law.

;

;It is not difficult to imagine that the reason why these scolders were detained was because their words and deeds met the definition of personal attack and insult, constituted an infringement on the victim, and were even suspected of illegal crimes, rather than general "swearing someone". The development of mobile Internet technology has only made personal attacks, insults, slander and defamation more convenient, and has even turned it into a "service" that can be traded on the platform. Technology itself is neutral, and there will naturally be "services to praise" and "services to scold". These "emotional needs" are rooted in the depths of human nature. "Screaming service" seems to be a new thing, but its core is quite old.

;

;Thirdly, since "cussing service" is a new business format supported by Internet technology, technological progress may also give rise to newer "swearing" business formats. This is probably worthy of careful consideration and strict enforcement. Alert. Generative AI, represented by the large language model ChatGPT, may bring about an even crazier and unimaginable future. It is conceivable that today's "scolding services" are just real people "taking orders and scolding" on the Internet. What if it is "AI scolding"?

;

;Nowadays, AI-trained face-changing, onomatopoeia, and composition are almost real. It is completely possible to clone a real person’s digital life in cyberspace, and then use a virtual number/account to intervene in reality. If you are scolded by a real-life AI dummy with a voice that is exactly the same as in real life, or by a completely virtual AI dummy, and the content of the insult is highly consistent with your personal information, and the person involved is difficult to trace , the various troubles and legal risks caused by it will definitely be several orders of magnitude higher than today's scolding by real people, which will bring greater difficulties to the protection of personality rights.

;

;For example, if you think that someone in real life has scolded you, in fact, it is just a third party that has purchased an AI scolding service that only extracts and uses the timbre and voice characteristics of a real person. You may mistakenly have an actual interaction with the real person. Conflict, and all this is the result of manipulation by a third party. The problem this creates is to some extent isomorphic to video head-swapping.

;

;Take the recent popularity of "AI dubbing" as an example. From Trump to singer Taylor Swift, everyone can speak Mandarin with their own distinctive voice. "AI is replacing voice workers." The prospect is not far away. If this technology is also used to "scream on someone's behalf", the consequences will be even more sensational than if a real person scolds someone on their behalf. Imagine that one day your communication tool receives "insulting audio and video messages" from relatives, friends and even celebrities. The mental damage alone may be enough for you, and it will also take time and effort to resolve misunderstandings.

;

;Therefore, in the face of the nascent "cussing service" and the raging generative artificial intelligence, it is indeed necessary to proactively clarify its boundaries and define which swearing behaviors are infringing and which are suspected of illegal crimes. Purchase Do service providers who curse others need to be held accountable?
